An EHC needs assessment is a detailed look at your child's education, health and social care needs. It is the first step towards getting an Education, Health and Care (EHC) plan.

What is an EHC needs assessment

An Education, Health and Care (EHC) needs assessment looks at your child's special educational needs, any health needs related to their SEND, and any social care needs. It brings together advice from different professionals to build a full picture of what your child needs to learn and thrive.

After the assessment, the council decides whether your child needs an EHC plan. An EHC plan is a legal document that sets out the support your child must receive.

Who can request an assessment

Any of the following people can ask for an EHC needs assessment:

  • You — as a parent or carer of a child aged 0 to 25
  • Young people aged 16 to 25 — in their own name
  • Your child's school or nursery
  • A doctor — such as your child's paediatrician
  • Social care — a social worker or other professional

You do not need the school's permission to request an assessment. You have the right to ask the council directly.

How to request an assessment

Write to the Gloucestershire County Council SEND team. Your request should include:

  • your child's name, date of birth and address
  • the name of your child's school or setting
  • why you think your child needs an assessment
  • what support has already been tried and how it has helped (or not helped)

You can send your request by:

  • Email: send@gloucestershire.gov.uk
  • Post: SEND Team, Gloucestershire County Council, Shire Hall, Gloucester GL1 2TG

SENDIASS can help you write your request. Get free help from SENDIASS

What happens and how long it takes

The whole process, from your request to a decision on whether to issue an EHC plan, must take no more than 20 weeks.

Week 1 to 6: Decision to assess

The council has 6 weeks to decide whether to carry out an assessment. They will look at whether your child has or may have special educational needs, and whether an EHC plan may be needed.

You will get a letter telling you the decision.

Week 6 to 16: The assessment

If the council agrees to assess, they will gather advice from:

  • an Educational Psychologist
  • your child's school or setting
  • health professionals (coordinated by NHS Gloucestershire)
  • social care (if relevant)
  • any other specialist your child sees

Your views and your child's views will also be gathered. This is a legal requirement.

Week 16: Decision

The council decides whether to issue an EHC plan. You will be told in writing.

Week 16 to 20: Draft plan

If the council decides to issue a plan, you will receive a draft EHC plan within 15 working days. You can comment on it and request changes before it is finalised.

If the council says no

If the council decides not to carry out an assessment, or decides after the assessment not to issue an EHC plan, you have the right to appeal.

Before you can appeal to the SEND Tribunal, you must contact a mediation adviser. They will give you a certificate, even if you decide not to go through mediation.

You have 2 months from the decision letter to register your appeal (or 1 month from the mediation certificate, whichever is later).

Read more about your rights and how to appeal

Useful evidence to include with your request

Your request is more likely to be accepted if you include evidence. This could be:

  • reports from school about what support has been tried
  • your child's school SEND support plan
  • reports from any specialists (speech therapist, occupational therapist, etc.)
  • letters from your GP or paediatrician
  • your own account of your child's difficulties

Do not worry if you do not have all of these. The council must still consider your request.

Key timescale

20 weeks from request to EHC plan (or decision not to issue one).

6 weeks for the council to decide whether to assess.
